etymologies: mid 17th century (in an earlier sense). From classical Latin molybdaena a kind of lead ore, also as the name of a plant from ancient Greek μολύβδαινα a kind of lead ore, angler's plummet from μόλυβδος lead + -αινα, suffix forming nouns

definitions: (A) Any of various substances resembling lead, especially molybdenite (molybdenum disulphide). Now chiefly historical. (b) The metallic element molybdenum. Now chiefly historical.

notes.text: The use of the word as the name of the element was prevalent from 1790 to 1820, the period immediately following its first isolation from its ore molybdenite.
